name: Ginger Pork Rolls with Eggplant
description: Perfectly juicy and savory Ginger Pork Rolls with Eggplant! This is something that you won't find on menus at your local Japanese restaurants, but the combination of pork, eggplant, and shiso leaf is simply amazing.
recipeIngredient: ½ lb thinly sliced pork loin ((1 package shabu shabu meat))
½ tsp ginger ((grated, with juice; from a 1-inch, 2.5-cm knob))

recipeInstructions.text: Gather all the ingredients.
recipeInstructions.name: Gather all the ingredients.

recipeInstructions.text: Grate the ginger and measure ½ tsp ginger (grated, with juice).
recipeInstructions.name: Grate the ginger and measure ½ tsp ginger (grated, with juice).

recipeInstructions.text: In a small bowl, combine all the ingredients for the sauce: 2 Tbsp soy sauce, 2 Tbsp mirin, 1 Tbsp sake, 1 tsp sugar, and the grated ginger.
recipeInstructions.name: In a small bowl, combine all the ingredients for the sauce: 2 Tbsp soy sauce, 2 Tbsp mirin, 1 Tbsp sake, 1 tsp sugar, and the grated ginger.

recipeInstructions.text: Peel 2 Japanese eggplants with a peeler and soak the peeled skin in water.
recipeInstructions.name: Peel 2 Japanese eggplants with a peeler and soak the peeled skin in water.

recipeInstructions.text: Cut the eggplant into 2-inch (5-cm) pieces widthwise, and cut each piece in half.
recipeInstructions.name: Cut the eggplant into 2-inch (5-cm) pieces widthwise, and cut each piece in half.

recipeInstructions.text: Then, cut each piece into 4 sticks and soak in water for 10 minutes to remove the bitterness and prevent from changing the color.
recipeInstructions.name: Then, cut each piece into 4 sticks and soak in water for 10 minutes to remove the bitterness and prevent from changing the color.

recipeInstructions.text: Now cut the eggplant skin into julienne strips and continue to soak in water.
recipeInstructions.name: Now cut the eggplant skin into julienne strips and continue to soak in water.

recipeInstructions.text: Remove any moisture on the eggplant with a paper towel.
recipeInstructions.name: Remove any moisture on the eggplant with a paper towel.

recipeInstructions.text: Wrap 2 eggplant sticks with a thin slice of pork. Continue with the rest of the ½ lb thinly sliced pork loin.
recipeInstructions.name: Wrap 2 eggplant sticks with a thin slice of pork. Continue with the rest of the ½ lb thinly sliced pork loin.

recipeInstructions.text: Sprinkle half of 2 Tbsp potato starch or cornstarch on the pork rolls and spread over the meat. Then, flip over and spread the remaining potato starch or cornstarch. Remove any excess starch.
recipeInstructions.name: Sprinkle half of 2 Tbsp potato starch or cornstarch on the pork rolls and spread over the meat. Then, flip over and spread the remaining potato starch or cornstarch. Remove any excess starch.

recipeInstructions.text: In a large nonstick frying pan, heat 1 Tbsp toasted sesame oil on medium heat. Add the pork rolls.
recipeInstructions.name: In a large nonstick frying pan, heat 1 Tbsp toasted sesame oil on medium heat. Add the pork rolls.

recipeInstructions.text: Cook them until all sides are golden browned.
recipeInstructions.name: Cook them until all sides are golden browned.

recipeInstructions.text: Cover the pan with a lid and cook on medium-low heat, until the eggplant is tender, roughly 2–3 minutes.
recipeInstructions.name: Cover the pan with a lid and cook on medium-low heat, until the eggplant is tender, roughly 2–3 minutes.

recipeInstructions.text: Add the sauce to the pan.
recipeInstructions.name: Add the sauce to the pan.

recipeInstructions.text: Coat the pork rolls well by rotating them and spooning the sauce over.
recipeInstructions.name: Coat the pork rolls well by rotating them and spooning the sauce over.

recipeInstructions.text: Serve the pork rolls on a plate and pour the sauce on top.
recipeInstructions.name: Serve the pork rolls on a plate and pour the sauce on top.

recipeInstructions.text: In the same pan (without washing), add the eggplant skin and ½ tsp miso.
recipeInstructions.name: In the same pan (without washing), add the eggplant skin and ½ tsp miso.

recipeInstructions.text: Mix well together and cook on medium-low heat until tender, about 2–3 minutes. Put the skins on top of the eggplant.
recipeInstructions.name: Mix well together and cook on medium-low heat until tender, about 2–3 minutes. Put the skins on top of the eggplant.

recipeInstructions.text: Roll up 4 shiso leaves (perilla/ooba) and cut into chiffonade strips.
recipeInstructions.name: Roll up 4 shiso leaves (perilla/ooba) and cut into chiffonade strips.

recipeInstructions.text: Garnish the pork rolls with shiso leaves. If you like it spicy, serve with a dab of yuzu kosho (Japanese citrus chili paste). You can put a tiny bit of it on the pork roll and enjoy!
recipeInstructions.name: Garnish the pork rolls with shiso leaves. If you like it spicy, serve with a dab of yuzu kosho (Japanese citrus chili paste). You can put a tiny bit of it on the pork roll and enjoy!

review.reviewBody: Hi Nami, I'm not using a non-stick fry pan. What can I do so the meat will not stick? Add more oil?

Hi,
I love your recipes. I will cook some of your recipes for a dinner party in a few days. I'm wondering about the Roasted Sesame Oil used for frying in this recipe. Doesn't that burn easily?
Best.
Gerry.

Great recipe. I'm not usually a fan of eggplant but my husband is, so I'm always trying to find ways to eat it that I think are good. I went to our local chinese butcher and had him slice pork for me and then to the Vietnamese grocer for shiso (perilla) and then to the Indian grocer for Asian eggplant. We don't have a Japanese grocery here but I can make do. 

BTW I love yuzukosho. I first had it with gyoza in Osaka and had to buy a jar to bring home. Now I buy it online. We eat it like mustard - with almost anything, not just japanese food.
How would you recommend reheating the left overs? Toast it up or just microwave?
